messages:
Researchers from CSAIL - MIT have developed a soft robotic cube that uses a series of spring-loaded metal tongues to jump, bounce, and roll. In this video, we watch the process of building a cube in just one minute.

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/wbGK309yYD4

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Building a soft robotic cube

Engineers at MIT have fabricated transparent gel robots that can perform a number of fast, forceful tasks for the first time. These robots may have future applications including assisting in surgical operations.

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/XEZI308zNIE

Video produced and edited by: Melanie Gonick/MIT
Hydrogel robot footage: Hyunwoo Yuk/MIT Soft Active Materials Lab Fast and forceful gel robots

At two times during the year, the setting sun aligns with the Infinite Corridor at MIT. In mid-November and in late January, when this occurs, and atmospheric conditions are right, sunlight streams down the entire 825 feet of the corridor. This celestial phenomenon is known as MIThenge.

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT MIThenge

A glimpse of the morning snowfall.

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Snowy campus

Two MIT chalkers caught in the act with good tidings. ☃

Featured chalk artists: Junior, Aaron Lin and Freshman, Sunny Tian.
Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT MIT Chalkers

A team of MIT engineers show they can predict a liquid's droplet size distribution, including the likelihood of producing very big and very small droplets, based on one main property: the liquid's viscoelasticity, or stickiness. 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/UboJ306YRGd

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT
High speed video: Bavand Keshavarz/Gareth H. McKinley/nnf@mit.edu
Music sampled from, "Air Hockey Saloon," by Chris Zabriskie Predicting the range of droplet sizes for sticky fluids

MIT engineers have transformed spinach plants into sensors that can detect explosives and wirelessly relay that information to a handheld device similar to a smartphone. 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/9Ehb305K63a

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT
Infrared/fluorescent images: Min Hao Wong Plant-to-human communication

Imobilare is a b-boy crew at MIT that provides opportunities for students to learn how to breakdance and improve their b-boying skills. Here, two members show us how they breakdance their way toward the end of the semester.

Learn more about Imobilare: http://imobilare.mit.edu/

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT
B-boys: Tomohiro Maeda and Jeffrey Lu, Class of 2018. Study Break

MIT researchers have come up with a simple, inexpensive system for developing artificial muscles. The key ingredient? Nylon fiber.

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/7tXK306sGbC

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Muscles Made of Nylon

Heat is a powerful force that can affect a material in many ways. For example, almost all solid materials when heated, inevitably expand. It is only in very rare instances certain materials do the opposite and actually shrink when heated. It is this class of "metamaterials" a team of engineers are interested in. 

Learn more: http://news.mit.edu/2016/3-d-printed-structures-shrink-when-heated-1025

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Heat-induced shrinkage

Inspired by hairy, semiaquatic mammals such as beavers and sea otters, a group of MIT engineers are fabricating fur-like rubbery pelts learn how these mammals stay warm and even dry while diving underwater. 

Learn more: mitsha.re/6e2J304T00N

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Furry Wetsuits

A group of MIT researchers took a detailed look at 125 U.S. auto models and found those emitting less carbon are the least expensive to drive overall. Their CarbonCounter app allows you to look up emissions rates for your vehicle or one you are considering buying or leasing. (Learn more: http://mitsha.re/oUM1304C6iZ)

Visit their online app: http://carboncounter.com/

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT CarbonCounter: Online app allows consumers to research low-emi...

Red Bull Flugtag is an annual event in which competitors attempt to fly a homemade aircraft off a platform 33 feet in the air. This year, Flugtag came to Boston and the MIT Monkey Ballers entered the competition. 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT MIT Monkey Ballers build a plane for Red Bull Flugtag 2016

A rugged new hydrogel hybrid from MIT Mechanical Engineering could be used to make artificial skin and longer lasting contact lenses. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/FwBK301GcWa

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT New hydrogel that doesn't dry out

How to draw the MIT seal in less than 2 minutes: 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT

#MIT2016 marks 50 years of the cardinal jackets worn at Commencement by 50-year alumni.

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT The Red Coats Are Coming

In the heart of MIT's campus, the MIT Museum Studio and Compton Gallery lets students share their creative visions in the fields of science, technology, architecture, history, and art. 

Watch: http://mitsha.re/Zm9YP 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Timeline Photos

Engineers in CSAIL - MIT have developed an ingestible origami robot that can deliver drugs and remove accidentally swallowed batteries. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/zeUF300969v

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Robotic surgeon in a pill

Engineers have developed a material that can protect and tighten skin, smooth wrinkles, and potentially be used to deliver drugs to treat skin conditions. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/4bKe3002OEA

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Engineering a second skin

Spring is just around the corner... 🌞

Photo: Melanie Gonick/MIT Timeline Photos

MIT undergrads don't take normal classes in January. So what do they do they do instead? LOTS. Enjoy a visual snapshot of Independent Activities Period at MIT.

Learn more about IAP: http://web.mit.edu/iap/

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Independent Activities Period: A Visual Journey

Top 15 posts of 2015 – No. 7: MIT's origami microbot on the move! Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) A tiny origami robot from CSAIL - MIT climbs, swims, and carries loads twice its weight! Read more: http://mitne.ws/1HwBZro  

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT

#TBT Wow! A 1957 time capsule meant to be sealed for 1,000 years was unexpectedly unearthed during construction at the MIT.nano site. More from MIT News: http://mitsha.re/UNSpl  

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Time capsule discovered at MIT

Physics fun: A new model developed by MIT engineers predicts the force required to tie simple knots.

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Untangling the mechanics of knots

"Our vision is to eliminate waste." MIT spinoff LiquiGlide brings nonstick coating to consumer packaging. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1BTLIqK 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Engineering nonstick coatings to reduce waste

A tiny origami robot from CSAIL - MIT climbs, swims, and carries loads twice its weight! Read more: http://mitne.ws/1HwBZro

At the MIT Costume Shop, students transform paper into incredible garments!

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT MIT Costume Shop

"I think a goal that we should have is to get more people to look through a telescope." 

Observe@MIT allows the MIT community to view the cosmos above campus. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/1F4RZOr

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Gazing at the cosmos with Observe@MIT

MIT's origami team, OrigaMIT, has been building an enormous three-dimensional fractal out of business cards. Here's a look at their effort to build a level-3 Menger sponge!

Learn more about paperfolding at MIT: http://mitsha.re/1MUtapV

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Building a Menger Sponge 3-D fractal at MIT

19 snow events and counting in 2015. Thank you to the facilities team keeping MIT running this winter!

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT with photos by Dominick Reuter In the Snow: Winter 2015 at MIT

During MIT's Independent Activities Period, students participating in the "Forces Frozen" workshop experimented with structural 
ice shells made from fabric frozen in place. Watch: http://mitsha.re/1yMxHaP

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Forces Frozen: Structures made from frozen fabrics Through the power of shape and curvature, very thin shells can achieve impressive strength and stiffness, even when they are made only from frozen water-soak...

Top 10 posts of 2014: No. 1 - Robo-cheetah

MIT's robotic cheetah can now run and jump on its own! Full story: http://mitne.ws/1s2M0pT

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT

Top 10 posts of 2014: No. 6 - Math at MIT

"If we can understand how mathematics relates to the world, then we can make a better world.”

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT

We love chemistry! Enjoy this inside look at MIT's Club Chem. 

Club Chem website: http://mitsha.re/1waa3nn 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Club Chem at MIT

What happens when 500 MIT students teach 3,000 high-school students over one weekend at MIT? Welcome to MIT Splash! 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/1u9Veg1 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT SPLASH! at MIT

Quantum entanglement, which Einstein once skeptically viewed as “spooky action at a distance,” is, in fact, real. Stars align in test supporting “spooky action at a distance” Physicists address loophole in tests of Bell’s inequality, using 600-year-old starlight.

Top 16 posts of 2016: No. 1 - Gravitational waves detected

Using the LIGO observatory, a team led by MIT and Caltech researchers made the first direct detection of gravitational waves, confirming Albert Einstein’s theory of general relativity. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/Yb0yR gph.is

Top 16 posts of 2016: No. 6 - Happy Birthday, Einstein!

This year we honored the birth of Albert Einstein with the discovery of gravitational waves. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/Yb0yR 

Image via GIPHY. gph.is

Top 16 posts of 2016: No. 9 - "We did it again!"

For the second time, the LIGO Scientific Collaboration detected gravitational waves from colliding black holes, further solidifying Albert Einstein's theory of relativity. For second time, LIGO detects gravitational waves Signal was produced by two black holes colliding 1.4 billion light years away.

MIT researchers working on the LIGO gravitational wave experiment were among the scientists awarded a Breakthrough Prize last night. Congrats to all! 

More from MIT News: http://mitsha.re/omSb306PA4P $25 Million in Breakthrough Prizes Given in Science and Math The awards went to more than a thousand physicists, life scientists and mathematicians in areas like genetics and string theory.

Time to science! The LIGO gravitational wave experiment is back online, ready to make new discoveries about the universe. LIGO back online, ready for more discoveries Upgrades make detectors more sensitive to gravitational waves.

“I realized that #physics was the most beautiful thing I’d ever studied.” —Libby Tolman, MIT Department of Physics Fusing theory and practice Grad student Libby Tolman melds the elegance of theoretical physics with practical applications of nuclear science.

MIT physicists are proposing a new experiment to detect a dark matter particle called the axion. 

If successful, the effort could crack one of the most perplexing unsolved mysteries in particle physics, as well as finally yield a glimpse of dark matter. Team simulates a magnetar to seek dark matter particle Detecting “axion” particles may solve longstanding problem in particle physics.

Kiosks from MIT Lincoln Laboratory (Official) and MIT DUSP may soon provide basic services after natural disasters like Hurricane Matthew. Art and science merge in a disaster readiness haven Innovative off-grid PREPHubs structures house basic services needed in the aftermath of a disaster.

Researchers from MIT and MIT Lincoln Laboratory report an important step toward practical quantum computers. Toward practical quantum computers Built-in optics could enable chips that use trapped ions as quantum bits.
An exhaustive search for so-called “sterile” neutrinos has come up empty. Neutrino search finds no evidence of “hidden” particle If discovered, sterile neutrinos may explain dark matter.

Weird science from the MIT Department of Physics. MIT scientists find weird quantum effects, even over hundreds of miles Neutrinos traveling 450 miles have no individual identities, according to MIT analysis.

How can a vehicle navigate to stay within its lane when bad weather obscures road markings? Researchers from MIT Lincoln Laboratory have an answer. Pinpointing vehicles with high precision under adverse weather conditions MIT Lincoln Laboratory radar system achieves centimeter-level localization; could help driverless cars stay in lane when road markings are obscured.

Blinded with science: Researchers in the MIT Department of Physics have discovered a new way of generating light, using graphene. Researchers discover new way to turn electricity into light, using graphene By slowing down light to a speed slower than flowing electrons, researchers create a kind of optical “sonic boom.”

“We did it again!” For the second time, the LIGO Scientific Collaboration has detected gravitational waves from colliding black holes, further solidifying Albert Einstein's theory of relativity. Full story: http://mitsha.re/7qYU301i1L1

This animation represents the merger of two black holes and the gravitational waves that ripple outward during the event. The black holes — representing those detected by LIGO on Dec. 26, 2015 — were 14 and eight times the mass of the sun until they merged into a single black hole 21 times the sun's mass. One solar mass was converted to gravitational waves. In reality, the area near the black holes would appear highly warped, and the gravitational waves would be difficult to see directly.

Video: LIGO/T. Pyle LIGO again detects gravitational waves

Congrats to MIT's Rai Weiss, 2016 winner of The Kavli Prize in Astrophysics! Weiss shares the award and $1 million with Kip Thorne and Ronald Drever of Caltech for the detection of gravitational waves using the LIGO experiment. 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/wyK8300R0X0

Images via the Kavli Prize. Timeline Photos

System from the RLE at MIT - Research Laboratory of Electronics at MIT could cut explosives detection time from minutes to microseconds. Speedy terahertz-based system could detect explosives Spectroscopic system with chip-scale lasers cuts detection time from minutes to microseconds.

"Creating the Lincoln Laboratory Supercomputing Center has been a goal for the team for many years, and it is tremendously rewarding to see it come to fruition," said Jeremy Kepner,  laboratory fellow, and head of the MIT Lincoln Laboratory (Official) Supercomputing Center (LLSC). Lincoln Laboratory establishes a supercomputing center New facility will enable interactive, high-performance computing for data analysis.

Congratulations to scientists and engineers of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration who have won a special $3 million Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics for their work in detecting gravitational waves! LIGO researchers awarded Special Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics Team that detected gravitational waves to share $3 million prize.

Meet MIT physicist Nuh Gedik, who peers into the high-speed activities of subatomic particles that inhabit exotic materials and physical states. Nuh Gedik: Peering into the heart of matter MIT physicist uses laser beams to study exotic electronic phenomena at high speeds.

Happy birthday, Albert Einstein! We got you a special gift this year: The first direct detection of gravitational waves 〰️〰️〰️ http://mitsha.re/Yb0yR

Image via GIPHY. media.giphy.com

#TBT One week ago, results from the #LIGO experiment shook the world. A new video recounts the discovery of gravitational waves, from the scientists' point of view: http://mitsha.re/Yb4YY LIGO Detects Gravitational Waves After a decades-long quest, The MIT-Caltech collaboration LIGO Laboratories has detected gravitational waves, opening a new era in our exploration of the uni...
Front page of The New York Times: LIGO found gravitational waves! Full report from Dennis Overbye '66: http://mitsha.re/Ygdqi Timeline Photos

“I would love to see Einstein’s face if he could read this article that we just put out! It’s a wonderful proof that all of this incredible stuff is in his equations.” –Prof. Emeritus Rainer Weiss http://mitsha.re/Yb4YY 

More on today's announcement of LIGO's discovery of gravitational waves: http://mitsha.re/Yb0yR #EinsteinWasRight

Video: MIT News/MIT Video Productions LIGO discovery: Einstein would be proud

Did you know? The LIGO gravitational wave detector was conceived by Prof. Emeritus Rainer Weiss at MIT nearly 40 years ago as a way to prove Einstein’s theory of relativity. Q&A: Rainer Weiss on LIGO’s origins MIT physicist developed the concept for LIGO as a teaching exercise.

Groundbreaking physics: Using the LIGO observatory, a team led by MIT and Caltech scientists has made the first direct detection of gravitational waves, proving correct Albert Einstein’s theory of general relativity. Full story: http://mitsha.re/Yb0yR 

Image: LIGO/R. Hurt giphy.com

Happy #FibonacciDay! Today, 11/23, we celebrate the numbers of the Fibonacci sequence. MIT Department of Physics Prof. Leonid Levitov explores how they appear in nature: http://mitsha.re/UYO5D

Photo: Maia Weinstock Timeline Photos

Congrats to Associate Professor Ed Boyden and all MIT researchers honored at this year's Breakthrough Prize awards! Edward Boyden wins 2016 Breakthrough Prize in Life Sciences MIT physicists share prize in fundamental physics; Larry Guth and Liang Fu win New Horizons Prizes.

How can technology improve response efforts after a natural disaster? The MIT Lincoln Laboratory is developing tools to assist agencies in the wake of events such as today's powerful earthquake in Asia. Technology confronts disasters Research and development at MIT Lincoln Laboratory will help agencies better respond to disasters and humanitarian crises.

New from RLE at MIT - Research Laboratory of Electronics at MIT: engineered viruses that can kill dangerous bacteria, including those for which there are no effective antibiotics. Viruses join fight against harmful bacteria Engineered viruses could combat human disease and improve food safety.

Breakthrough science: A team from the MIT Department of Physics and RLE at MIT - Research Laboratory of Electronics at MIT has created a Bose-Einstein condensate in a record-high magnetic field. A new look at superfluidity MIT team creates a superfluid in a record-high magnetic field.

#TBT Jay Forrester SM '45 with the Whirlwind computer in the MIT Digital Computer Lab, 1957. Learn about Forrester's pioneering contributions to systems engineering in the current MIT Technology Review: http://mitne.ws/1NOFlpx

Photo: MIT Lincoln Laboratory (Official) Timeline Photos

Researchers at RLE at MIT - Research Laboratory of Electronics at MIT supercool molecules to 500 nanokelvins - almost absolute zero: mitne.ws/1Mo7F1w #physics MIT team creates ultracold molecules At near absolute zero, molecules may start to exhibit exotic states of matter.

New discovery from the MIT Department of Physics: Earth-sized #exoplanets with circular orbits, similar to our solar system. Circular orbits identified for small exoplanets Observations of 74 Earth-sized planets around distant stars may narrow field of habitable candidates.

A new detector developed by researchers from the MIT Department of Physics “sees” single electrons and could help measure neutrino mass: http://mitne.ws/1EnRgLa New tabletop detector “sees” single electrons Magnet-based setup may help detect the elusive mass of neutrinos.

MIT Lincoln Laboratory (Official) has a new Foucault pendulum! 

Photo: Jon Barron #aroundMIT Replicating a simple but elegant experiment MIT Lincoln Laboratory's installation of a pendulum re-creates Foucault's seminal demonstration of Earth's rotation.

To help encourage future engineers, the MIT Lincoln Laboratory (Official) recently hosted a wearable-tech workshop for high-school girls. Lincoln Laboratory hosts first "Make Your Own Wearables" workshop for high-school girls Hands-on projects in wearable technology introduce girls to mechanical design and electrical engineering.

"Contemplating the possibility of pilot wave theory might lead to a fresh interpretation of quantum weirdness, one that prompts physicists to rethink their longstanding assumptions about the true nature of the quantum world." In a piece for NOVA Next, writer Jennifer Ouellette describes thought-provoking research from MIT's John Bush and Daniel Harris. Quantum Physicists Catch a Pilot Wave - The Nature of Reality — NOVA Next | PBS In October 1927, some of the greatest minds in physics gathered for the Fifth Solvay International Conference to debate the troubling implications of the then-nascent theory... Read Full Post

The LLRISE program at MIT Lincoln Laboratory (Official) is teaching aspiring engineers from around the U.S. to build small radar systems. LLRISE: Building radars at Lincoln Laboratory The Lincoln Laboratory Radar Introduction for Student Engineers (LLRISE) program is a summer workshop teaching students how to build small radar systems. (Le...

On this date in 1951, the MIT Lincoln Laboratory (Official) was established to build the nation's first air defense system. Today, the Laboratory is home to research and development pertinent to national security on behalf of the military services, the Office of the Secretary of Defense, and other government agencies. #MIThistory MIT Lincoln Laboratory: History Since its opening in 1994, the Microelectronics Laboratory has enabled key advances in electronics. This booklet (pdf) highlights 20 of the most significant of these innovations.

Congratulations to MIT physicist Alan Guth for winning the prestigious Kavli Prize. Alan Guth shares $1 million Kavli Prize in Astrophysics MIT physicist lauded for his groundbreaking theory of cosmic inflation.

RLE at MIT - Research Laboratory of Electronics at MIT and MIT Department of Physics researchers discover a new way to selectively control light. More: http://mitne.ws/1pAiD7I (Photo: Weishun Xu and Yuhao Zhang) Timeline Photos

MIT Department of Physics researchers propose using distant quasars to test Bell’s theorem. More: http://mitne.ws/1glj81M

(Image: ESO/M. Kornmesser) Timeline Photos

MIT Department of Physics researchers identify one of the earliest #stars in the #universe. The discovery suggests that the very first generation of stars may not have been as powerful as previously thought. More: http://mitne.ws/1fZ8qzO

(Image: NASA) Timeline Photos

New kind of see-through screen from MIT Department of Physics RLE at MIT - Research Laboratory of Electronics at MIT could be applied as a thin plastic coating on ordinary glass. More: http://mitne.ws/1eQ67MQ

(Video: Melanie Gonick, MIT News) Transparent Displays Transparent displays have a variety of potential applications — such as the ability to see navigation or dashboard information while looking through the wind...
MIT Department of Physics finds the creation of entanglement simultaneously gives rise to a #wormhole. More: http://mitne.ws/IVunni Timeline Photos

New scheme could enable laser rangefinders to infer depth from a hundredth as much light — and to produce images from only one nine-hundredth the light. More: http://mitne.ws/1bdwit5 #3D #Camera RLE at MIT - Research Laboratory of Electronics at MIT Timeline Photos

Learn more about #MIT senior Margo Batie, who plays hard on the rugby field and works hard in the physics lab. More: http://mitne.ws/1enkAAb  MIT Department of Nuclear Science and Engineering MIT Department of Physics Timeline Photos

Using gold nanoparticles, MIT researchers have devised a new way to turn blood clotting on and off. 

This image is a colorized electron micrograph. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/13HgkYV

MIT Mechanical Engineering MIT Lincoln Laboratory (Official) Timeline Photos
#MIT physicists discover a whole new way to trap light, which could lead to new types of lasers and sensors. http://mitne.ws/1b001Ls #science #research Timeline Photos
On the hunt for neutrinos: MIT physicist Joseph Formaggio seeks new ways to detect and measure the elusive particles. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/11Nb569 Timeline Photos

In a new paper, MIT physicists describe a new way to predict the risk of collapse in a natural population based on variations in population density in neighboring regions. Early warning signs of population collapse - MIT News Office Spatial measurements of population density could reveal when threatened natural populations are in danger of crashing.

Researchers at MIT’s Research Laboratory of Electronics have come up with a new mathematical framework for evaluating compressed-sensing schemes that factors in the real-world performance of hardware components. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/Xpid6R Timeline Photos
Check out what researchers from MIT’s Research Laboratory of Electronics did with MIT's logo! http://mitne.ws/XkLqQZ Timeline Photos

NASA, MIT's Lincoln Laboratory and others have opened up a contest (for those 18 and younger) to name an asteroid. So, what would you name it? 

Learn more about the contest at http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2012/nasa-announces-asteroid-naming-contest-for-students-0905.html Timeline Photos

A team of researchers from the MIT Department of Physics and Harvard University has achieved a crucial long-term goal of efforts to create quantum devices: the ability to convert a laser beam into a stream of single photons, or particles of light, in a controlled way. Single-photon transmitter could enable new quantum devices - MIT News Office Long-sought goal for quantum devices — the ability to transmit single photons while blocking multiple photons — is finally achieved.

MIT physicist and CERN researcher answers questions on the Higgs boson announcement from CERN this morning. 3 Questions: Physicist Christoph Paus discusses newly discovered particle - MIT News Office Dozens of MIT physicists were part of the team that found what might be the Higgs boson. What does their discovery mean, and what’s next for particle physics?

Engineers in MIT IMES have found that a dietary supplement could be useful in treating obstructive sleep apnea in certain patients. A possible new approach to stopping obstructive sleep apnea Dietary supplement derived from tree bark shows promise for treating the disorder.

Astronomy news: Scientists from MIT and elsewhere have discovered seven Earth-sized planets around the nearby dwarf star TRAPPIST-1. Might life exist on one or more? 3Q: Julien de Wit on the discovery of seven temperate, nearby worlds Planets may harbor conditions suitable for sustaining liquid water — and thus life.

MIT's 2017 diversity luncheon in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. featured NASA Goddard Space Flight Center mission manager Aprille Joy Ericsson ’86, who noted that inclusion of women and minorities in STEM fields is "imperative." “Discrimination affects us all” Celebration of MLK features NASA mission manager Aprille Joy Ericsson ’86.

Want to find an exoplanet of your own? Now you can, using a public dataset of 1,600 nearby stars. Scientists make huge dataset of nearby stars available to public Users can search database of 1,600 stars to find signs of new exoplanets.

MIT comprises a diverse, international community of nearly 23,500 students, postdocs, faculty, and staff. MIT faculty alone hail from 73 countries — including the seven affected by the presidential executive order of Jan. 27. In this video, five MIT professors reflect on why international collaboration benefits science, engineering, and technology for all. Video: MIT Video Productions Tackling science and technology together

MIT scientists have uncovered how long the solar nebula — gas and dust that would be come the solar system — lasted. Scientists estimate solar nebula’s lifetime Study finds the swirling gas disk disappeared within the solar system’s first 4 million years.

Neuroscientists at MIT have adapted an MRI scanner to make it easier to scan infants’ brains as the babies watch movies featuring different types of visual input. A glimpse into the workings of the baby brain MRI scans reveal surprising similarities in activity patterns of infant and adult visual cortex.

When it comes to perceiving music, the human brain is much more tuned in to certain types of rhythms than others, according to a new study from MIT. How the brain perceives rhythm Study finds the brain is biased toward rhythms based on simple integer ratios.

A delicate balance between positive and negative emotion Neuroscientists identify two neuron populations that encode happy or fearful memories.

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT Are musical tastes cultural or hardwired in the brain?

A new study from MIT reveals that a brain region dedicated to reading has connections for that skill even before children learn to read. Study finds brain connections key to reading Pathways that exist before kids learn to read may determine development of brain’s word recognition area.

In a study of mice, an MIT team found that two of the genes that control cells’ circadian rhythms also function as tumor suppressors. Why working the night shift can pose a cancer risk New study reveals a link between circadian clock disruption and tumor growth.

47 years ago today, MIT computer scientist Margaret Hamilton's code landed humans on the moon.

“This study suggests that preferences for consonance over dissonance depend on exposure to Western musical culture, and that the preference is not innate,” says Josh McDermott of the Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences at MIT. Why we like the music we do New study suggests that musical tastes are cultural in origin, not hardwired in the brain.

What we've learned with NASA's New Horizons in the year since #PlutoFlyby: 3 Questions: Richard Binzel on what we've learned so far from New Horizons Professor Richard Binzel, NASA New Horizons scientist, describes a year of discovery since the spacecraft's historic 2015 Pluto encounter.

Scientists at MIT and elsewhere have identified the “first fingerprints of healing” of the Antarctic ozone layer, published in the journal Science. Scientists observe first signs of healing in the Antarctic ozone layer September ozone hole has shrunk by 4 million square kilometers since 2000.

Why do women leave engineering? A study led by MIT anthropologist Susan Silbey reveals a new answer. #stateofwomen Why do women leave engineering? Study: Group dynamics of teamwork and internships deter many women in the profession.

Cool news! MIT scientists have found the first direct evidence that black holes feed on clouds of cold gas. Scientists observe supermassive black hole feeding on cold gas Findings suggest two dining styles for black holes.

New from the MIT Department of Chemistry: Compounds found in fungi could be used to treat cancer. A new approach to chemical synthesis Communesins, originally found in fungus, could hold potential as cancer drugs.

A new study is opening the way for new classes of alloys with previously unseen combinations of properties. New metal alloys overcome strength-ductility tradeoff Promising new approach overturns widespead metallurgical assumption

Superbugs working together? A new MIT study finds bacteria resistant to different antibiotics can protect each other. Teamwork enables bacterial survival Strains of E. coli resistant to one antibiotic can protect other bacteria growing nearby.

How are certain diseases passed on through genes? A new MIT study sheds light on this important question. New approach to genetic analysis yields markers linked to complex diseases Study identifies new gene variants that may be targets for treating arrhythmia.
A new MIT study finds dust mites don’t just cause allergies — they can also harm DNA. Asthma linked to DNA damage Allergies induced by dust mites can harm DNA in lung cells.

“We know that pilots aren’t always looking out the window, and we know that people don’t always pay attention in whatever they’re doing,” says Mary “Missy” Cummings, associate professor of MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics. “The question is: Can you get people to pay attention enough, at the right time, to keep the system performing at a high degree?” Driving drones can be a drag - MIT News Office Study shows distractions may alleviate boredom and improve drone operators’ performance.

“They’re so small that you can put several [thrusters] on a vehicle,” says Paulo Lozano, a professor in MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics. He adds that a small satellite outfitted with several microthrusters could “not only move to change its orbit, but do other interesting things — like turn and roll.” MIT-developed ‘microthrusters’ could propel small satellites - MIT News Office As small as a penny, these thrusters run on jets of ion beams.

In an article for POLITICO, Professor Sanjay Sarma calls attention to the security of the Internet of Things, writing, “if leaders don’t think this through, and don’t create a framework for it to succeed, there’s a real chance that the full potential of the Internet of Things could be compromised.” Read more: http://mitne.ws/1Hxtqy7 I helped invent the Internet of Things. Here’s why I’m worried about how secure it is. I'm a mechanical engineering professor at MIT, and 17 years ago, with my colleagues David Brock, Kevin Ashton and Sunny Siu, I helped launch the research effort that laid some of the groundwork for the Internet of Things. As you might imagine, my life is pretty connected.

The researchers’ converter is a step-down converter, meaning that its output voltage is lower than its input voltage. In particular, it takes input voltages ranging from 1.2 to 3.3 volts and reduces them to between 0.7 and 0.9 volts. Researchers devise efficient power converter for internet of things Design reduces converter’s resting power consumption by 50 percent.

A study led by MIT and others has found that the rigging of Volkswagen vehicles to pass emissions tests will lead to 1,200 premature deaths in Europe due to resulting air pollution. Study: Volkswagen’s excess emissions will lead to 1,200 premature deaths in Europe Countries hit hardest by automaker’s emissions scandal include Germany, Poland, France, and Czech Republic.

Engineers and biologists at MIT have teamed up to design a new “living material” — a tough, stretchy, biocompatible sheet of hydrogel injected with live cells that are genetically programmed to light up in the presence of certain chemicals. Living sensors at your fingertips Cell-infused gloves and bandages light up when in contact with certain chemicals.

MIT startup Sistine Solar creates custom solar panels designed to mimic home facades and other environments, with aims of enticing more homeowners to install photovoltaic systems. Solar panels get a face-lift with custom designs Startup aims for wider U.S. solar adoption with photovoltaic panels that can display any image.

Many scientists are pursuing ways to treat disease by delivering DNA or RNA that can turn a gene on or off. However, a major obstacle to progress in this field has been finding ways to safely deliver that genetic material to the correct cells. Nanoparticle screen could speed up drug development New test helps identify particles for gene delivery or RNA interference.

MIT researchers have designed a voltaic cell sustained by stomach acids. The system can generate enough power to run small sensors or drug-delivery devices that can reside in the GI tract for extended periods. Engineers harness stomach acid to power tiny sensors Ingestible electronic devices could monitor physiological conditions or deliver drugs.

MIT engineers have genetically reprogrammed a strain of yeast so that it converts sugars to fats much more efficiently, an advance that could make possible the renewable production of high-energy fuels such as diesel. A step toward renewable diesel Chemical engineers program yeast to convert plant sugars into oils.

MIT researchers have now developed a theoretical model to predict the spectrum of light absorbed by aggregates of these pigments, based on their structure. How photosynthetic pigments harvest light New model could help scientists design materials for artificial photosynthesis.

MIT's new Election Data and Science Lab aims to improve how the U.S. election system works. MIT Election Data and Science Lab launches Founded by political scientist Charles Stewart III, the Election Lab focuses on non-partisan research, data, and analysis to improve elections.

Scientists in the MIT Department of Chemistry have discovered a new path to making drugs more effective. Catalyst adds fluorine-containing groups to make new compounds Introducing such groups to potential drugs could make them more effective.

MIT chemists have now developed a technique that allows them to print objects and then go back and add new polymers that alter the materials’ chemical composition and mechanical properties. Technique enables adaptable 3-D printing Once fabricated, objects can be altered by adding new polymers.

Researchers at CSAIL - MIT have developed a new computational model of a neural circuit in the brain. Model sheds light on purpose of inhibitory neurons Study suggests computational role for neurons that prevent other neurons from firing.

“Step by step, we are making encouraging progress across the Institute,” says Don Holmes, director of maintenance and utilities in MIT’s Department of Facilities. Campus greenhouse gas emissions down 7 percent since 2014 MIT releases results of its second campus-wide inventory.
#OTD In 1914: the beaver was chosen MIT's mascot because of its remarkable engineering and mechanical skill and its habits of industry.  Watch to learn more: https://youtu.be/kf4GP2-vSvQ gph.is

MIT chemical engineers have built three-dimensional arrays of antibodies that could be used as sensors to diagnose diseases such as malaria or tuberculosis. 3-D antibody arrays offer better sensing New tool could help diagnose malaria and other diseases.

MIT researchers present a way to make atom interferometry with Bose-Einstein condensates even more precise, by eliminating a source of error endemic to earlier designs. Hyperprecise measurement with Bose-Einstein condensates New atom interferometer could measure inertial forces with record-setting accuracy.

MIT scientists have found that extreme precipitation events in California and elsewhere should become more frequent as the Earth’s climate warms. Study finds more extreme storms ahead for California New technique predicts frequency of heavy precipitation with global warming.

“Forests of carbon nanotubes can transfer ink onto a surface like massive numbers of tiny pen quills.” Printable electronics New stamping technique creates functional features at nanoscale dimensions.

A new approach to microelectromechanical systems (MEMS), developed by a team of researchers at MIT, could offer a new way of making movable parts with no solid connections between the pieces, potentially eliminating a major source of wear and failure. 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT
Footage: Daniel Preston/Device Research Lab at MIT Movable microplatform floating on droplets

Top 16 posts of 2016: No. 4 - The next Albert Einstein?

Graduate student Sabrina Pasterski '14 is blowing our minds with her work in physics. She's Being Called the Next Albert Einstein A 22-Year-Old Harvard Ph.D. candidate could change our understanding of the universe.

Top 16 posts of 2016: No. 10 - Cancer-fighting bacteria

MIT engineers programmed E. coli bacteria to destroy cancer cells. Cancer-fighting bacteria Engineers program E. coli to destroy tumor cells.

What will the power grid of tomorrow look like? The MIT Energy Initiative provides some insight in a new report. MIT Energy Initiative report provides guidance for evolving electric power sector Experts call for regulatory, policy, and market transformation to realize potential of distributed energy technologies.

Researchers at MIT and Brigham and Women's Hospital have developed a new drug capsule that remains in the stomach for up to two weeks after being swallowed, gradually releasing its drug payload. This type of drug delivery could potentially assist in eliminating diseases such as malaria.

New hope for Alzheimer's patients? MIT researchers have developed a promising treatment using light stimulation. #MITBetterWorld

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/LUU9306UnMC

Video: Picower Institute for Learning and Memory
Animation: Sputnik Animation
Additional footage and music: Pond5 Light-based therapy for Alzheimer's disease

Despite many years of study, some of graphene’s fundamental properties are still not well-understood, including the way it behaves when something slides along its surface, until now: The science of friction on graphene Sliding on flexible graphene surfaces has been uncharted territory until now.

MIT researchers have discovered astonishing behavior of water confined in carbon nanotubes. Inside tiny tubes, water turns solid when it should be boiling MIT researchers discover astonishing behavior of water confined in carbon nanotubes.

Researchers at MIT and Brigham and Women's Hospital have developed a new drug capsule that remains in the stomach for up to two weeks after being swallowed, gradually releasing its drug payload. New capsule achieves long-term drug delivery Technology could aid in elimination of malaria and treatment of many other diseases.

New findings suggest a route toward using the world’s existing infrastructure for fuel storage and distribution, without adding net greenhouse emissions to the atmosphere. Turning greenhouse gas into gasoline New catalyst provides design principles for producing fuels from carbon dioxide emissions.
MIT researchers have now demonstrated that genetic circuits can be isolated within individual synthetic “cells,” preventing them from disrupting each other. mitsha.re

MIT Chemical Engineering (ChemE) alumnus Ricardo “Ricky” Rosselló ’01 is Puerto Rico's new governor. MIT Alumnus Elected Governor of Puerto Rico A biomedical engineer and neurobiologist by training, Ricky Rosselló ’01 was elected governor of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico on Nov. 8.

Scientists have found evidence that Pluto may harbor a liquid ocean just below its surface. Pluto’s icy, slushy heart Data from New Horizons mission suggest a water-ice ocean lies beneath Pluto’s heart-shaped basin.

Researchers at MIT and Massachusetts General Hospital have moved a step closer to a treatment to rapidly awaken patients after administration of a general anesthetic. Study suggests approach to waking patients after surgery Activating certain brain neurons may spur recovery from general anesthesia.

Researchers from MIT, Boston Children's Hospital, and Massachusetts General Hospital have joined forces in an ambitious new project to use magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to evaluate the health of fetuses. MRIs for fetal health Algorithm could help analyze fetal scans to determine whether interventions are warranted.

Now MIT researchers have developed an imaging technique that, for the first time, enables three-dimensional mapping of serotonin as it’s reabsorbed into neurons, across multiple regions of the living brain. Mapping serotonin dynamics in the living brain Imaging technique that creates 3-D video of serotonin transport could aid antidepressant development.

The future is here: MIT engineers have created bionic plants that can send us text messages when they detect dangerous chemicals. Nanobionic spinach plants can detect explosives After sensing dangerous chemicals, the carbon-nanotube-enhanced plants send an alert.

Researchers at MIT and elsewhere have developed a new way of driving fluid droplets across surfaces in a precisely controlled way. 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/3hqF305iFeT gph.is

“It’s not enough to have an original idea. You have to make that idea work for the world.” —Karen Gleason, MIT Chemical Engineering (ChemE) Karen Gleason: Inventing at the nanoscale and growing an innovation ecosystem MIT professor and associate provost modifies surfaces at the nanoscale while enhancing innovation around the Institute.

Promising news in the search for a cancer cure: MIT researchers have harnessed the immune system to destroy tumors. Fighting cancer with the power of immunity New treatment elicits two-pronged immune response that destroys tumors in mice.

MIT engineers say cellphones, laptops, and other electronic devices may face a higher risk of overheating, as a result of interactions between electrons and heat-carrying particles called phonons. Electron-phonon interactions affect heat dissipation in computer chips Study shows particle collisions may explain overheated circuits, improve thermoelectric devices.

“I don't think you can hack the election.” —MIT political scientist Charles Stewart III How healthy is the U.S. voting system? Professor Charles Stewart III explains why the U.S. electoral system is strong and how MIT research is making the voting process even more seamless.

Supercharger of the future: Introducing the first non-carbon supercapacitor, from scientists and engineers at MIT! #MITBetterWorld New kind of supercapacitor made without carbon Energy storage device could deliver more power than current versions of this technology.

Researchers at MIT and elsewhere have developed a technique to monitor Parkinson’s disease progression as patients interact with a computer keyboard. Monitoring Parkinson’s symptoms at home Keyboard-monitoring technique can detect motor difficulties as patients type.

Researchers at MIT and other institutions have created tiny freeze-dried pellets that include all of the molecular machinery needed to translate DNA into proteins, which could form the basis for on-demand production of drugs and vaccines. To produce biopharmaceuticals on demand, just add water Freeze-dried cellular components can be rehydrated to churn out useful proteins.

MIT researchers have designed nanosensors that can profile tumors and may yield insight into how they will respond to certain therapies. Nanosensors could help determine tumors’ ability to remodel tissue Measuring enzyme levels could help doctors select appropriate treatments.

MIT chemists have now shown that they can package three or more drugs into a novel type of nanoparticle, allowing them to design custom combination therapies for cancer. High-capacity nanoparticle Particles that carry three or more drugs hold potential for targeted cancer therapy.

A new study and "Carbon Counter" app from the MIT Institute for Data, Systems, and Society finds low-emissions vehicles cost less overall. How does yours stack up? Study: Low-emissions vehicles are less expensive overall Detailed look at 125 U.S. auto models finds those emitting less carbon are the least expensive to drive.

The human digestive tract contains trillions of bacteria, many of which help digest food and fight off harmful bacteria.

Recent studies have shown that some of these bacteria may influence, for better or worse, human diseases such as diabetes, heart disease, and cancer. Delivering beneficial bacteria to the GI tract Method that transports microbes through the stomach to the intestine may benefit human health.

How are you feeling? A new device from Prof. Dina Katabi and two MIT grad students uses wireless signals to read your emotions. Detecting emotions with wireless signals Measuring your heartbeat and breath, CSAIL device can tell if you’re excited, happy, angry, or sad.

MIT researchers and their colleagues are designing an imaging system that can read closed books. 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/MDCe3043KEk i.giphy.com

A new technique invented at MIT can precisely measure the growth of many individual cells simultaneously. Microchip enables fast, precise measurement of single-cell growth Device that measures growth of many individual cells simultaneously could lead to rapid tests for antibiotics and other drugs.

Solar, or photovoltaic (PV), cells, which convert sunlight into electrical energy, have a large role to play in boosting solar power generation globally, but researchers still face limitations to scaling up this technology.

A team of researchers from MIT and the Masdar Institute of Science and Technology may have found a way around this seemingly intractable tradeoff between efficiency and cost. New solar cell is more efficient, costs less than its counterparts Exposed in step-like formation, layers of new photovoltaic cell harvest more of sun’s energy.

MIT researchers have now added an extra layer of control over when and where the genome-editing system known as CRISPR occurs, by making the system responsive to light. Using light to control genome editing New technique offers precise manipulation of when and where genes are targeted.

MIT researchers were trying to develop a new battery, but it didn’t work out that way. Instead, thanks to an unexpected finding in their lab tests, what they discovered was a whole new way of producing the metal antimony — and potentially a new way of smelting other metals, as well. New method developed for producing some metals Using electricity rather than heat can reduce both energy costs and greenhouse gas emissions.

"I kept asking myself," says Gang Chen, the Carl Richard Soderberg Professor in Power Engineering, "Can we basically boil water on a rooftop, in normal conditions, without optically concentrating the sunlight?" Sponge creates steam using ambient sunlight Bubble-wrapped structure requires no mirrors or lenses to focus the sun’s heat.

What happens when carbon dioxide flows through deep saltwater reservoirs? Study reveals new physics of how fluids flow in porous media Key flow mechanisms, crucial to carbon sequestration and fuel-cell operation, have been visualized.
What would your cells tell you? Recording analog memories in human cells Engineers program human cells to store complex histories in their DNA.

An MIT spinout is preparing to commercialize a novel rechargeable lithium metal battery that offers double the energy capacity of the lithium ion batteries that power many of today’s consumer electronics. Doubling battery power of consumer electronics New lithium metal batteries could make smartphones, drones, and electric cars last twice as long.

A device from the MIT Department of Chemistry aims to improve ear infection diagnosis — and eliminate one of the leading causes of antibiotic resistance. A new eye on the middle ear Shortwave infrared instrument from MIT could see deeper, help improve diagnosis of ear infections.

Will we find life on Mars? If so, this MIT technique could help. New technique may help detect Martian life A novel interpretation of Raman spectra will help the 2020 Mars rover select rocks to study for signs of life.

A new study from the MIT Institute for Data, Systems, and Society finds switching vehicles to all-electric could yield a major reduction in U.S. transportation emissions. Can today’s EVs make a dent in climate change? Electric vehicles can meet drivers’ needs enough to replace 90 percent of vehicles now on the road.

A collaboration between MIT and Brazilian researchers has identified a promising drug target for three serious diseases. Targeting neglected diseases New enzyme-mapping advance could help drug development.

Although epidurals are generally regarded as safe, there are complications in up to 10 percent of cases, in which the needles are inserted too far or placed in the wrong tissue.

A team of researchers from MIT and Massachusetts General Hospital hopes to improve those numbers with a new sensor that can be embedded into an epidural needle. Needles that hit the right mark New sensor could help anesthesiologists place needles for epidurals and other medical procedures.

New material from the MIT Department of Chemistry could lead to energy-saving self-shading windows. 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/8N5V303bjnr i.giphy.com

If you want to model the effects of wing flexion on the crack’s propagation, or vice versa, you need to switch back and forth between these two levels of description, which is difficult. 

A team of researchers have developed a new programming language that handles that switching automatically. User-friendly language for programming efficient simulations New language can speed up computer simulations 200-fold or reduce the code they require by 90 percent.

Unless you’ve been following the subject closely, you may not have heard of one of the biggest barriers slowing the revival of global economic growth over the last decade. The safety trap Lack of secure investments is hindering growth globally, research finds.

The newest Airbus and Boeing passenger jets flying today are made primarily from advanced composite materials, but composite materials are surprisingly vulnerable. 

MIT aerospace engineers have found a way to bond composite layers in such a way that the resulting material is substantially stronger and more resistant to damage than other advanced composites. Carbon nanotube “stitches” strengthen composites Method to reinforce these materials could help make airplane frames lighter, more damage-resistant.

Now a portable production system, designed to manufacture a range of biopharmaceuticals on demand, has been developed by researchers at MIT. Portable device produces biopharmaceuticals on demand System would use microbes for manufacturing small amounts of vaccines and other therapies.

“I love to work on new ideas and develop new kinds of tools to tackle basic questions.” —Tim Wang, PhD student in the MIT Department of Biology Targeting genes by the thousands PhD student Tim Wang uses CRISPR to take a big-picture approach to cancer research.

A new app from researchers at MIT could allow homes, businesses, and institutions to monitor energy use of individual appliances and devices. What’s wasting power at home? Ask your app! New system from MIT can identify how much power is being used by each device in a household.

MIT researchers have developed a new technique for imaging brain tissue at multiple scales. Imaging the brain at multiple size scales New technique can reveal subcellular details and long-range connections.

To defeat it, says medical researcher and educator Paula Hammond, we need a new and powerful mode of attack. With her colleagues at MIT, Hammond engineered a nanoparticle one-hundredth the size of a human hair that can treat the most aggressive, drug-resis...

A new variation of the battery chemistry, which could be used in a conventional, fully sealed battery, promises similar theoretical performance as lithium-air batteries, while overcoming many of the drawbacks. New lithium-oxygen battery greatly improves energy efficiency, longevity New chemistry could overcome key drawbacks of lithium-air batteries.

Every 3-D experience starts with those clunky glasses, but that could soon change. New movie screen allows for glasses-free 3-D at a larger scale Prototype display enables viewers to watch a 3-D movie from any seat in a theater.

Synthetic biology allows researchers to program cells to perform novel functions such as fluorescing in response to a particular chemical or producing drugs in response to disease markers. Scientists program cells to remember and respond to series of stimuli New approach to biological circuit design enables scientists to track cell histories.

Biologists have long suspected that ants base their population-density estimates on the frequency with which they — literally — bump into other ants while randomly exploring their environments. Exploring networks efficiently Analysis of ant colony behavior could yield better algorithms for network communication.

Researchers at MIT’s research center in Singapore have developed a new microfluidic device that tests the effects of electric fields on cancer cells. MIT engineers have developed a new type of easily customizable vaccine that can be manufactured in one week. Engineers design programmable RNA vaccines Tests in mice show the vaccines work against Ebola, influenza, and a common parasite.

Your smartphone and other wireless devices could soon detect trace amounts of toxic gases. Wireless, wearable toxic-gas detector Inexpensive sensors could be worn by soldiers to detect hazardous chemical agents.

Researchers at MIT are making fluorescent polymer gels that change color when they’re shaken, heated, exposed to acid, or otherwise disrupted. The promise of fluorescent polymer gels Color-changing materials could be used to detect structural failure in energy-related equipment.

Researchers at MIT and elsewhere have found a new way of using mid-infrared lasers to turn regions of molecules in the open air into glowing filaments of electrically charged gas, or plasma. New mid-infrared laser system could detect atmospheric chemicals Laser pulses produce glowing plasma filaments in open air, could enable long-distance monitoring.

Engineering from nature: MIT researchers have found nanofibers from silk can be combined to create an excellent filtration system. Silk-based filtration material breaks barriers Engineers find nanosized building blocks of silk hold the secrets to improved filtration membranes.

Nearly half of the world’s population is at risk of infection by the dengue virus, yet there is no specific treatment for the disease. Now a therapy to protect people from the virus could be a step closer, thanks to a team at MIT. More: http://mitne.ws/12AyHzX

A new report by researchers at MIT and elsewhere finds that materials manufacturers will likely be unable to meet targets for carbon-emissions reductions by 2050. See what can be done about it: http://mitne.ws/10dKWP5 Timeline Photos

New research carried out at MIT and elsewhere has demonstrated for the first time that when inserted into a pool of liquid, nanowires — wires that are only hundreds of nanometers (billionths of a meter) across — naturally draw the liquid upward in a thin film that coats the surface of the wire. The finding could have applications in microfluidic devices, biomedical research and inkjet printers. Read the full story: http://mitne.ws/10k8MpA 
 Nanowires can lift liquids without power | MIT Video New research has demonstrated for the first time that when inserted into a pool of liquid, nanowires naturally draw the liquid upward in a thin film that coats the surface of the wire.

Simulating the flow of grains in silos, and in other geometries, has proven a tricky, centuries-old problem for scientists. Now researchers at MIT have devised a model of granular flow in three dimensions. The team found the model accurately predicts the results of granular flow experiments, including a flow configuration that has long puzzled scientists. http://mitne.ws/ZQMU7p Timeline Photos

New solar-cell design based on dots and wires: MIT researchers improve efficiency of quantum-dot photovoltaic system by adding a forest of nanowires. http://mitne.ws/14iYa0J

Images: Scanning Electron Microscope images show an array of zinc-oxide nanowires (top) and a cross-section of a photovoltaic cell made from the nano wires, interspersed with quantum dots made of lead sulfide (dark areas). A layer of gold at the top (light band) and a layer of indium-tin-oxide at the bottom (lighter area) form the two electrodes of the solar cell. Courtesy of Joel Jean, et al/Advanced Materials. Timeline Photos

Hitting HIV where it hurts: By pinpointing weak spots in viral proteins, scientists could hobble HIV's rapid evolution — and its ability to outrun new vaccines. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/WRUxMj

(Image: This scanning electron micrograph shows HIV particles infecting a human T cell. Credit: National Institutes of Health) Timeline Photos

Scientists believe the new approach of nanoscale drug delivery can push modern medicine further. Delivering RNA or DNA to specific cells offers the promise of selectively turning genes on or off, while nanoscale devices that can be injected or implanted in the body could allow doctors to target drugs to specific tissues over a defined period of time. Find out more:  http://mitne.ws/Ynh26N 

Image by Paula T. Hammond and Erik C. Dreaden: Human breast cancer cells (purple) are targeted by nanoparticles (green) developed by MIT professor Paula Hammond. The particles bind to receptors overexpressed by cancer cells. Timeline Photos

Researchers have found that some widely used formulas for predicting how rapidly technology will advance — notably, Moore’s Law and Wright’s Law — offer superior approximations of the pace of technological progress. The new research is the first to directly compare the different approaches in a quantitative way. http://mitne.ws/XPjx4X How to predict the progress of technology MIT researcher finds Moore's Law and Wright's Law best predict how technology improves.

Preventing glass from fogging or frosting up is a longstanding challenge with myriad applications: eyeglasses, cameras, microscopes, mirrors and refrigerated displays, to name but a few. So far there has been no systematic way of testing different coatings and materials to see how effectively they work under real-world conditions. Until now: http://mitne.ws/XQr9Vx MIT-developed coating could prevent frost buildup | MIT Video A team of MIT researchers has found a coating that outperforms others not only in preventing foggy buildups, but also in maintaining good optical properties without distortion.

The Little Devices group at MIT has developed a solar-powered autoclave, used to sterilize surgical tools, that can be built and repaired in developing countries using locally available parts and materials. The device would cost less than existing kerosene or electric sterilizers and would require no fuel or power. Read the story: http://mitne.ws/YxQmA5

In this video, D-Lab instructor José Gómez-Márquez talks about other medical technologies he has developed for use in the developing world. TR35: José Gómez-Márquez | MIT Video Jose Gomez-Marquez, program director for the Innovations in International Health program at MIT, demonstrates some of the medical technologies he is developing for use in countries such as Nicaragua.

Drawing upon the chemical composition of rock features on Mercury's surface, MIT scientists have proposed that the planet may have harbored a large, roiling ocean of magma very early in its history, shortly after its formation about 4.5 billion years ago. http://mitne.ws/XndqW1 Mercury may have harbored an ancient magma ocean Massive lava flows may have given rise to two distinct rock types on Mercury's surface.

A new technique developed by MIT researchers provides the first direct views of how drops and bubbles adhere to surfaces — and how they let go. The findings could be applied to engineering industrial surfaces with controlled adhesion in applications ranging from large desalination and power plants to consumer products.

Find out more about this research: http://mitne.ws/15sZxsV Scanning droplets | MIT Video Animation showing how the base of a water droplet forms small "necks" as it moves across a surface that has pillars etched on it.

The annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) highlighted a diverse roster of MIT researchers presenting work on everything from human-robot interactions to the convergence of biology and engineering, as well as hands-on demonstrations ranging from tiny model rockets to Lego models of chemical reactions in the atmosphere. AAAS annual meeting puts MIT science and technology on display - MIT News Office The 2013 conference, held last week in Boston, featured research presentations, hands-on demonstrations.

Your smartphone snapshots could be converted into professional-looking photographs with just the touch of a button, thanks to a processor chip developed at MIT. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/W1qQc1 Timeline Photos

Standard public-key encryption is secure as long as an attacker knows nothing other than the public key. But financial institutions and other large organizations seek security against more sophisticated attacks, called chosen-ciphertext attacks (CCAs), in which the attacker also has examples of successful decryption. 

CSAIL - MIT researchers have devised a new technique for taking one of these vulnerable, error-prone CCA schemes and turning it into a secure CCA scheme. This could result in the development of more-secure encryption protocols. http://mitne.ws/XbsiFJ Timeline Photos

Engineers at MIT have built an automated system that can rapidly produce 3-D, micron-resolution images of thousands of zebrafish larvae and precisely analyze their physical traits. Researchers say the system offers a comprehensive view of how potential drugs affect vertebrates. http://mitne.ws/VSs1Fv Timeline Photos

MIT engineers have created genetic circuits in bacterial cells that not only perform logic functions, but also remember the results, which are encoded in the cell’s DNA and passed on for dozens of generations. The circuits could be used as long-term environmental sensors, efficient controls for biomanufacturing, or to program stem cells to differentiate into other cell types. http://mitne.ws/TUWcz8

(Image: Liang Zong and Yan Liang) Timeline Photos

Enlisted in the fight against HIV, MIT engineers and scientists are contributing new technology, materials and computational studies. Find out more in the latest entry of our series, "Engineering Health." http://mitne.ws/WRa3Xd Timeline Photos

From India to Stanford, crossing over to the startup world and now at MIT, Devavrat Shah has spanned disciplines to devise algorithms that can predict consumer preferences or what topics will trend on Twitter. Find out more about his work: http://mitne.ws/YUmfcz Timeline Photos

A new approach developed by researchers at MIT and Rutgers University could improve the efficiency of devices that harness power from temperature differences. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/VIrxH6

This 12-foot-high system housed in an MIT lab has demonstrated the principles of a new humidification-dehumidification system that cleans "produced water" from natural gas wells. The new technology — which MIT researchers say requires far less energy than previous systems — could lead to inexpensive, efficient desalination plants in developing countries. http://mitne.ws/VzPdbs Timeline Photos

Quantum dots have the potential for many applications, but have faced a series of hurdles to improved performance. Now, an MIT team says that it has succeeded in overcoming all these obstacles at once. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/11dGAuN Timeline Photos

A field experiment conducted in Morocco and co-authored by an MIT economist showed that residents are willing to pay more in order to have water piped into their homes. And despite the impact on their finances, people in households that gain running water report significant improvements in happiness. http://mitne.ws/W4pecZ Timeline Photos

The gene that causes Huntington's disease does most of its damage in the basal ganglia, shown in pink. See how an MIT researcher devised a new way to manipulate heat. http://mitne.ws/RJYNuF Timeline Photos

MIT researchers are designing tools to analyze cells at the microscale, which could lead to big medical discoveries. http://mitne.ws/ZlLMX4 Timeline Photos

MIT researchers built some pretty amazing little machines in 2012. Check them out: http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear Timeline Photos

This year, MIT researchers engineered a device that delivers a tiny, high-pressure jet of medicine through the skin without the use of a hypodermic needle. The device can be programmed to deliver a range of doses to various depths — an improvement over similar jet-injection systems that are now commercially available. http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear Timeline Photos
A new spectroscopy technique developed at MIT and Case Western Reserve University could help doctors better identify breast tumors. http://mitne.ws/TZqLAV Timeline Photos
As the holiday shopping season winds down, we just have to ask: If you could have any of these not-yet-to-market innovations from MIT, which would you want?

A possible path to earlier cancer detection: Researchers at MIT have developed nanoparticles that can home to a tumor and interact with cancer proteins to produce thousands of biomarkers, which can then be easily detected in a patient’s urine. http://mitne.ws/SGfIzF Timeline Photos

Ever wonder how to get into MIT? MIT Engineering, in its "Ask an Engineer" series, tackles that question: http://engineering.mit.edu/live/news/2237 How do I get into MIT? It should be less about getting in and more about getting it right—cultivate the interests and work on the projects you love anyway…
Do you have a consistent approach to your financial choices? A new study shows that at most a third of us do. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/RwIQJk Timeline Photos

Are you up in our neck of the woods, leaf peeping this weekend? If so, you'd be surprised how much carbon dioxide those beautiful leaves carry with them. The mathematics of leaf decay - MIT News Office A mathematical model reveals commonality within the diversity of leaf decay.

Diving into a pool from a few feet up allows you to enter the water smoothly and painlessly, but jumping from a bridge can lead to a fatal impact. The water is the same in each case, so why is the effect of hitting its surface so different? Probing the mysteries of cracks and stresses - MIT News Office Analysis of molecular-level fracture and stress mechanisms could have broad implications for understanding materials’ behavior.
Using ultrasound waves, researchers from MIT Chemical Engineering (ChemE) boost skin’s permeability to drugs. Getting (drugs) under your skin - MIT News Office

“What it does is take whatever carbon is available, and stores it in the form of a polymer, which is similar in its properties to a lot of petroleum-based plastics,” Brigham says. By knocking out a few genes, inserting a gene from another organism and tinkering with the expression of other genes, Brigham and his colleagues were able to redirect the microbe to make fuel instead of plastic. Teaching a microbe to make fuel - MIT News Office Genetically modified organism could turn carbon dioxide or waste products into a gasoline-compatible transportation fuel.

Researchers in MIT's Department of Biological Engineering will receive up to $32 million over the next five years to develop a technology platform that will mimic human physiological systems in the laboratory, using an array of integrated, interchangeable engineered human tissue constructs. DARPA and NIH to fund ‘human body on a chip’ research - MIT News Office MIT-led team to receive up to $32 million from DARPA and NIH to develop technology that could accelerate pace and efficiency of pharmaceutical testing.

MIT chemistry professor Stephen J. Lippard, who has spent much of his career studying platinum drugs, has now identified a compound that kills cancer cells better than cisplatin, the most commonly used platinum anticancer drug. The new compound may be able to evade cancer-cell resistance to conventional platinum compounds. New drug candidate shows promise against cancer - MIT News Office Platinum compound may offer an alternative to cisplatin, a widely used chemotherapy agent.

Researchers led by an MIT postdoc have analyzed an artificial system that models the light-capturing method used by deep-sea bacteria. Researchers explain how dye-based nanotubes can help harvest light’s energy - MIT News Office Tiny cylinders help reveal how natural-light-harvesting antennae collect light with exceptional efficiency.

“Random-matrix theory allows us to understand how disorder in a material affects its electrical properties" - Jiahao Chen, MIT Chemistry Department  New technique allows simulation of noncrystalline materials Multidisciplinary team develops mathematical approach that could help in simulating materials for solar cells and LEDs.
Harnessing heat radiation that most solar cells ignore All-carbon solar cell harnesses infrared light

In under two minutes, learn how these polymers may change the future of microchips.  Tinier Wires [Video] Researchers at MIT have found a new way of making complex three-dimensional structures using self-assembling polymer materials that form tiny wires and junctions.

"...new research shows that the region may be ripe for another devastating earthquake" Researchers find building seismic strain in Azerbaijan Deformation caused by colliding tectonic plates may threaten Azerbaijani capital, oil supplies to Europe.

"The secret lies in a pattern of tiny inverted pyramids etched into the surface of the silicon. These tiny indentations, each less than a millionth of a meter across, can trap rays of light as effectively as conventional solid silicon surfaces that are 30 times thicker." Textured surface may boost power output of thin silicon solar cells MIT team finds new approach to trapping  light efficiently in thin-film silicon solar cells.

Using a technique known as “nucleic acid origami,” chemical engineers have built tiny particles made out of DNA and RNA that can deliver snippets of RNA directly to tumors, turning off genes expressed in cancer cells. Researchers achieve RNA interference, in a lighter package - MIT News Office Pared-down nucleic acid nanoparticle poses less risk of side effects, offers better targeting.

Using stiffer pavements on the nation’s roads could reduce vehicle fuel consumption by as much as 3 percent — a savings that could add up to 273 million barrels of crude oil per year, or $15.6 billion at today’s oil prices. This would result in an accompanying annual decrease in CO2 emissions of 46.5 million metric tons.  Civil engineers find savings where the rubber meets the road - MIT News Office Study shows that pavement deflection under vehicle tires makes for a continuous uphill drive that increases fuel consumption.

In a new paper, published in Cell today, the researchers showed that staggering the doses of two specific drugs dramatically boosts their ability to kill a particularly malignant type of breast cancer cells. One-two punch knocks out aggressive breast cancer cells - MIT News Office New MIT study shows that staggered delivery of cancer drugs is far more effective than administering them at the same time.

Mucus often elicits strong revulsion, but to MIT biological engineer Katharina Ribbeck, it is a fascinating material: “Without it, we wouldn’t be able to smell, we wouldn’t be able to reproduce, and we would all be the victims of pathogens." Immune protection from an unexpected source - MIT News Office MIT biological engineers find that proteins in mucus help ward off viral infection.

Every year, more than a million Americans receive an artificial hip or knee prosthesis. Such implants are designed to last many years, but in about 17 percent of patients who receive a total joint replacement, the implant eventually loosens and has to be replaced early, which can cause dangerous complications for elderly patients.

To help minimize these burdensome operations, a team of MIT chemical engineers has developed a new coating for implants that could help them better adhere to the patient’s bone, preventing premature failure.  New coating for hip implants could prevent premature failure - MIT News Office Nanoscale films developed at MIT promote bone growth, creating a stronger seal between implants and patients’ own bone.

“You normally have to put a lot of energy into converting carbon dioxide into something useful,” says Kimberly Hamad-Schifferli, an associate professor of mechanical engineering and biological engineering. “We demonstrated hybrid copper-gold nanoparticles are much more stable, and have the potential to lower the energy you need for the reaction.”  Hybrid copper-gold nanoparticles convert CO2 May reduce greenhouse gas emissions

A team of MIT researchers has developed a new type of nanoparticle that can synthesize proteins on demand. Once these “protein-factory” particles reach their targets, the researchers can turn on protein synthesis by shining ultraviolet light on them — effectively creating cancer drugs at the site of the tumor. Nano-sized ‘factories’ churn out proteins - MIT News Office Tiny particles could manufacture cancer drugs at tumor sites.

“You can use anything green, even grass clippings” as the raw material, Mershin says. Harnessing nature’s solar cells - MIT News Office Photovoltaic panels made from plant material could become a cheap, easy alternative to traditional solar cells.

The researchers’ new coreset technique takes data sets with large numbers of variables and find approximations of them with far fewer variables. Making big data manageable Technique shrinks data sets while preserving their fundamental mathematical relationships.

Making computers explain themselves New training technique would reveal the basis for machine-learning systems’ decisions.

“The goal of all this is to present the interesting stuff to the data scientists so that they can more quickly address all these new data sets that are coming in,” says Max Kanter MEng ’15. Automating big-data analysis With new algorithms, data scientists could accomplish in days what has traditionally taken months.

“It’s like Photoshop for 3-D materials, allowing you to design objects made of new composite materials that have the optimal mechanical, thermal, and conductive properties that you need for a given task,” says PhD student Kiril Vidimče. For children with speech and language disorders, early-childhood intervention can make a great difference in their later academic and social success. But many such children go undiagnosed until kindergarten or even later.

Researchers at CSAIL - MIT and Massachusetts General Hospital’s Institute of Health Professions hope to change that. Automated screening for childhood communication disorders Computer system could help identify subtle speech, language disorders in time for early intervention.

Researchers from CSAIL - MIT and Indiana University at Bloomington describe a new system that permits database queries for genome-wide association studies but reduces the chances of privacy compromises to almost zero. After thousands of hours of work, MIT researchers have released the first major database of fully annotated English sentences written by non-native speakers. First major database of non-native English Resource could yield linguistic insights, practical applications for non-native English speakers.

CSAIL - MIT researchers demonstrate a robot that, by learning from human workers, can help assign and schedule tasks in fields ranging from medicine to the military. Researchers at the MIT Laboratory for Computational Physiology have taken an alternative approach to clinical research by freely releasing ICU data to researchers globally, with a goal of crowdsourcing the knowledge generation process. New software from researchers at CSAIL - MIT could make databases much easier for laypeople to work with. Democratizing databases With a new tool, any competent spreadsheet user can construct custom database interfaces.

A strategy for “convergence” research to transform biomedicine Report calls for more integration of physical, life sciences for revolutionary advances in biomedical research.

Robots that sound so real, they fool humans. Artificial intelligence produces realistic sounds that fool humans Video-trained system from MIT’s Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Lab could help robots understand how objects interact with the world.
